text-align: left
div.span: Liars apply known lie structures like structures of ridiculousness or insanity to make their opponents' statements seem false.

div.style: text-align: left
text-align: left
div.span: Liars apply truth structures like confidence structures (happiness signals, signals of expectations of good things) to make their own statements seem true.

div.style: text-align: left
div.span: 1. Calling it ridiculous

div.style: text-align: left
text-align: left
div.span: 2. Applying standard distortion to make it seem ridiculous (emphasis, assurance, exaggerating, dismissing) and confidence structures to seem right (fake laugh indicating fake happiness) and simplicity structures (adding only a few distortions) to seem like they're telling the truth

div.style: text-align: left
div.span: 3. Specifying case where it's not true (changing what they said to make it seem false or specifying distorted case where it's false) - "yeah, he's the president of Canada, and Coca-Cola, and Mars, too!"

div.style: text-align: left
text-align: left
div.span: 4. Ad hominem (change position of statement to the position of statements that a moron would make)

div.style: text-align: left
text-align: left
div.span: 5. Ascribe emotional incentive to say it to make it seem false (you must be drunk, just drink to deal with it like everyone else does, you must be going through a hard time, need a compliment, need attention)

div.style: text-align: left
text-align: left
div.span: 6. Ascribe to stupidity/insanity/drugs (did you take too many uppers, "youll hate this fact if you didnt like that fact", did the cult draw you in with coupons or something, the local meth must be good, the crack is strong with this one)

div.style: text-align: left
text-align: left
div.span: 7. React with balanced structures (sanity, happiness, concern, pity) to truth-teller to discredit them (sorry you need to believe that to feel good)

div.style: text-align: left
text-align: left
div.span: 8. Make ridiculous claim that everyone would identify as a lie to seem like a truth-teller who would only tell an obvious lie (youre just mad that your underdog candidate Deez Nuts was robbed again)

Have cheap/minimal evidence ready to counteract attacks
(cheap gestures contradicting true statement)

Lack of effort
(trying to give impression they don't have to try)

div.div: Trying to force definition of happiness/confidence/honesty that favors them

box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div: Trying to gain trust to prevent them from examining facts/logic

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 139px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1041px; margin-left: 886px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 688px; height: 1px; padding-top: 287px; margin-left: 616px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
text-align: left
div.span: A query to generate this info, as well as find a solution to the problem of 'find/build a function to detect lying':

div.style: text-align: left
text-align: left
text-align: left
div.span: - apply conceptual interface, then intent, then structural, and if enough info is identified at that point, organize info in a system structure like a network as a rough initial structure of relevance, applying structural interface regularly after that to identify & fit new interface structures like connections & patterns into the network organization structure, which will act as an input constant (like a set of definitions or data sources would be).

div.style: text-align: left
div.span: - apply filter & optimization structures to identify solution metrics with acceptable prediction rate & apply to complete function, updating constants & applying interface queries as needed (like pattern interface) to further organize or identify new relevant structures.

div.style: text-align: left
text-align: left
text-align: left
div.span: - apply conceptual interface (identify confidence, calmness, happiness, ridiculousness, boredom as core concepts of lying)

div.style: text-align: left
div.span: - apply intent interface (identify reasons to lie, like making conversation, boredom, or to get physical resources)

div.style: text-align: left
div.span: - apply structural interface (identify structures of lies & related concepts, as well as general structures like opposites (truth))

div.style: text-align: left
div.span: - apply system interface (to organize other info structures identified, like creating a network between lie types & lie functions)

div.style: text-align: left
text-align: left
text-align: left
div.span: Once these interfaces are applied, you'll have the info below. At this point, you've formatted info in a useful way to allow finding connections, patterns, & optimizations. Our solution involves finding a function to identify lying, so we need to find a solution metric to measure how well we've accomplished that, and then optimize for that metric.

div.style: text-align: left
div.span: Metrics can include:

div.style: text-align: left
div.span: - lie type clusters

div.style: text-align: left
div.span: - combination of lie structures (or proxy structures like related conceptual structures)

div.style: text-align: left
div.span: - combination of core lie functions

div.style: text-align: left
div.span: - difference from truth structures

div.style: text-align: left
div.span: - a combination of these metrics

div.style: text-align: left
div.span: For example, if info matches x false confidence structures, y reasons to lie, and has no contradicting matching truth structures, assign it a probability z of being a lie type, then additional probabilities for which lie types if new information is found indicating specific types.

div.style: text-align: left
text-align: left
text-align: left
div.span: Once you find a solution metric with an acceptable prediction success rate, apply it as a filter to finish the identificatioin function (using info structures found in interface application as a set of constants to use as input & update if additional structures are identified).

div.style: text-align: left
text-align: left

switch.text: A query to generate this info, as well as find a solution to the problem of 'find/build a function to detect lying'...

box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 82px; height: 1px; padding-top: 791px; margin-left: 290px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 378px; height: 1px; padding-top: 382px; margin-left: 1306px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
text-align: left
div.span: 1. What is the reaction that the lie gets? Assume that's the intent of the lie, and then ask how that reaction might benefit them (this statement makes me think highly of them, although their statement doesn't seem to be true or verifiable, and I tend to reward people I think highly of in this way, which is possibly what they wanted)

div.style: text-align: left
text-align: left
div.span: 2. Check for truth & lie structure ratio (is what they said probable/verifiable, are they providing info supporting their statement)

div.style: text-align: left
text-align: left
div.span: 3. Look for low-cost structures that are alternatives to high-cost structures of the same intent (what's the low-cost way to seem good or avoid punishment - denying it, accusing someone else of it, etc). Honest people tend to favor high-cost structures because they make a point of earning things with work. Lower cost structures involve fewer functions/inputs/components than higher cost structures.

High cost structures
to fulfill "avoid punishment" intent

a.text: Viewer does not support full SVG 1.1
